headline: Chickpeas and Kale in Spicy Pomodoro Sauce
description: This bright and spicy vegetarian chickpea dish comes together in minutes. Get the recipe at Food & Wine.

video.description: Chef Missy Robbins of Brooklyn’s Lilia restaurant swaps chickpeas for pasta in her riff on spicy pomodoro. She finishes the dish with a shower of fresh herbs and salty pecorino cheese.
video.name: Chickpeas and Kale in Spicy Pomodoro

name: Chickpeas and Kale in Spicy Pomodoro Sauce
recipeIngredient: One 28-ounce can whole peeled Italian tomatoes, crushed by hand
One 8-ounce bunch of Tuscan kale, stemmed and chopped
Two 15-ounce cans chickpeas, rinsed and drained
Torn basil and marjoram leaves, for garnish
Finely grated Pecorino Romano, for serving

recipeInstructions.text: In a large saucepan, heat the olive oil over low heat. Add the garlic and cook, stirring occasionally, until very fragrant but not browned, about 5 minutes. Add the tomatoes, fennel seeds, crushed red pepper and a generous pinch of salt. Cook over moderately low heat, stirring occasionally, until the tomatoes break down and the sauce is thickened, about 25 minutes.

Stir the kale into the sauce and cook over moderately low heat, stirring occasionally, until wilted, about 3 minutes. Stir in the chickpeas and cook until heated through, about 3 minutes. Season with salt. Spoon into bowls and garnish with torn basil and marjoram leaves. Top with finely grated pecorino and serve hot.

review.reviewBody: I made a half recipe last night and dove into the leftovers this morning. Made according to recipe except I had no chickpeas so I used a can of white beans instead. I'm trying to add more meatless and veggie packed meals and this was delicious, spicy and filling. I already want to make it again!
Love the use of chick peas

This is a go-to recipe in my house. It's uncomplicated, and oh-so special and flavorful, I don't see a reason to change a thing. I have forwarded the recipe to every single guest and client I have made it for. The fact that it is uber-nutritious just ups the ante in my book (I'm a certified natural foods chef and culinary educator), and when I get a double-whammy like this from a recipe, it goes into my repertoire on steady rotation. Love, love, love this recipe! Just a thought on the perceived excess of olive oil - it actually increases the bio-availability of the lycopene and other nutrients and antioxidants in the tomato sauce, not to mention the nutritional value of olive oil, in and of itself.

This is a go-to recipe in my house. It's so special and so flavorful, I never change a thing. I have forwarded the recipe to every single guest I have made it for. The fact that it is uber-nutritious just ups the ante in my book (I'm a natural foods chef), and when I get a double-whammy like this from a recipe, it goes into my repertoire on steady repeat. Love, love, love this!

I made the recipe pretty much as written and it came out delicious! I was a little short on garlic and halved the amount of crushed red pepper, as I don't like things too spicy, and it was fine for me but my boyfriend added extra pepper for his portion. I think the balance was perfect between all the ingredients. We had it with bread to soak up some of the juice.

Solid recipe, nutritious and flavorful- nice healthy gluten free twist subbing pasta for chick peas, 5stars for that, however 1/2 cup of oil is ridiculous, so much unnecessary extra fat- 2T will do the trick just fine! Also fennel is interesting, I find it to be overpowering. Many herbs will work beautifully here such as oregano, parsley, etc. Buon appetito!
Chickpeas + Spicy + Kale == A perfect blend.

This is a great recipe. Easy to make. I do not cook the san marzano tomatoes (Bianco) as long as recommended, perhaps 15 minutes or so. I also cut down the garbanzos to 1 can and use beet greens instead of kale. Sub in Aleppo pepper, and add some dried porcini mushroom dust for some umami. Lots of pecorino too.

item.name: Chickpeas and Kale in Spicy Pomodoro Sauce
